name: wallrice
description: WallRice is a modern web app to transform your images with beautiful color palettes. Upload, select colors, and create stunning colorized wallpapers in seconds.
readme_summary: WallRice is a modern web application that allows users to colorize their uploaded images and wallpapers using custom or pre-defined color palettes. It offers advanced settings for fine-tuning the colorization process and provides realistic previews within device mockups.
primary_use_case: Transforming user-uploaded images into stylized wallpapers by applying custom or thematic color palettes.
cover_image_prompt: A digital artist's workbench where a blank canvas is being transformed into a vibrant, stylized wallpaper. On one side, a user is selecting colors from a beautiful, glowing palette inspired by popular terminal themes (like Catppuccin or Dracula). On the other side, the original image is being fed into a stylized 'colorizer' machine that uses glowing, perceptually uniform color streams (representing Lab color space) to apply the selected palette. The output is a stunning, colorized wallpaper displayed on a sleek monitor, with subtle UI elements and device mockups (macOS/Linux style) in the background. The scene should be clean, modern, and visually appealing, rendered in a 3D isometric illustration style with soft, ambient lighting.

name: spotatui
description: A fully standalone Spotify client for the terminal. Native streaming included, no daemon required.
readme_summary: Spotatui is a standalone, native Spotify client for the terminal, built with Rust and powered by Ratatui. It offers a lightweight and efficient way to interact with Spotify directly from your command line, featuring real-time audio visualization and synced lyrics.
key_features: Standalone Spotify client for the terminal
primary_use_case: To provide a fully functional and resource-efficient Spotify client experience directly within the command-line interface, enabling users to control music playback, view lyrics, and visualize audio without needing a separate graphical application or daemon.
cover_image_prompt: A stylized, glowing terminal window emerges from a swirling nebula of musical notes and sound waves. Inside the terminal, a minimalist, abstract representation of a sound equalizer pulses with vibrant colors, visualizing the music being streamed. A subtle, ethereal silhouette of a person is seen interacting with the terminal, their hands near the glowing screen. Small, abstract data streams flow from the nebula into the terminal, representing the music input. The overall mood is futuristic and immersive, with a dark background and neon highlights. The style should be a 3D isometric illustration, emphasizing the integration of music and the digital interface.

name: pingerr
description: Find the most optimal DNS server for your router/machine
readme_summary: Pingerr is a shell script that benchmarks over 60 public DNS servers to identify the fastest and most reliable option for your network. It analyzes DNS query times and network latency, providing a weighted score and color-coded results for easy interpretation.
primary_use_case: Finding the most optimal DNS server for a router or machine by benchmarking public DNS resolvers.
cover_image_prompt: A wise old owl, perched on a network router, holding a magnifying glass over a map of the internet. The owl is meticulously examining glowing pathways representing DNS servers, with some pathways shining brightly (fast) and others dim (slow). Small, subtle digital particles representing data packets flow around the owl and router. In the background, a clean, minimalist interface displays a simple graph showing speed comparisons. The scene is set in a cozy, dimly lit study, emphasizing focus and analysis. The overall style is a 3D isometric illustration with a warm, inviting color palette, highlighting the 'pingerr' name subtly etched on the router.

name: MK_DroidScreenCast
description: Full access to your Android smartphone via ADB
readme_summary: MK DroidScreenCast is a Python-based application that provides full access to an Android smartphone via ADB and Scrcpy. It offers both a command-line interface (CLI) and a web-based panel for managing and streaming the Android device's screen to a PC over USB or Wi-Fi.
key_features: Universal Android device manager using ADB and Scrcpy
Control smartphone from PC via USB or Wi-Fi
Interactive CLI and modern Web Panel interfaces
Automatic environment setup and tool downloads (ADB, Scrcpy)
Multiple connection methods: USB, Wireless Pairing (Android 11+), USB -> Wi-Fi
Device manager for saving IP/ports and quick reconnections
Configurable Scrcpy settings (quality presets, bitrate, frame size, keyboard modes, display options)
Real-time WebSocket statuses in Web Panel
Device and preset management in Web Panel
primary_use_case: To provide a user-friendly interface for remotely controlling and streaming an Android device's screen to a PC, simplifying the process of debugging, development, or general usage.
cover_image_prompt: A split scene: on one side, a person is comfortably seated at a desk with a laptop, looking relaxed. On the other side, a vibrant, detailed miniature replica of their Android phone is projected holographically above the laptop, with its screen clearly visible and interactive. Glowing lines of data flow from the laptop to the phone, symbolizing control and streaming. Subtle UI elements resembling the application's CLI and Web Panel are visible on the laptop screen. The overall mood is seamless integration and effortless control. The repository name 'MK DroidScreenCast' is subtly integrated into the holographic display. Style: 3D isometric illustration with a clean, modern aesthetic and a vibrant color palette.

name: python-cqrs
readme_summary: Python CQRS is a framework for implementing the Command Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) pattern in Python applications. It facilitates the separation of read and write operations, enhancing scalability, performance, and maintainability, with added support for event-driven architecture concepts like event sourcing, sagas, and transaction outbox patterns.
primary_use_case: Implementing CQRS and event-driven architectures in Python applications for distributed systems.
cover_image_prompt: A wise old librarian meticulously organizing two distinct sections of a vast library: one section filled with 'Action' scrolls (commands) being carefully filed away, and another section with 'Information' books (queries) being readily accessible on display shelves. A subtle stream of glowing 'event' particles flows from the 'Action' section to the 'Information' section, signifying the data flow. Small, stylized icons representing FastAPI and Kafka are subtly integrated into the library's architecture. The overall mood is one of organized efficiency and knowledge dissemination, rendered in a clean, 3D isometric illustration style with a warm, inviting color palette.
